feed.title: fastpages
feed.subtitle: An easy to use blogging platform with support for Jupyter Notebooks.

entry.title: Fastpages Notebook Blog Post
entry.content:
About¶

This notebook is a demonstration of some of capabilities of fastpages with notebooks.

With fastpages you can save your jupyter notebooks into the _notebooks folder at the root of your repository, and they will be automatically be converted to Jekyll compliant blog posts!

Front Matter¶

Front Matter is a markdown cell at the beginning of your notebook that allows you to inject metadata into your notebook. For example:

  • Setting toc: true will automatically generate a table of contents
  • Setting badges: true will automatically include GitHub and Google Colab links to your notebook.
  • Setting comments: true will enable commenting on your blog post, powered by utterances.

More details and options for front matter can be viewed on the front matter section of the README.

Markdown Shortcuts¶

put a #hide flag at the top of any cell you want to completely hide in the docs

put a #collapse flag at the top of any cell if you want to hide that cell by default, but stil have it be visible to the reader:

#collapse
import pandas as pd
import altair as alt

put a #collapse_show flag at the top of any cell if you want to show that cell by default, but give the reader the option to hide it:

#collapse_show
cars = 'https://vega.github.io/vega-datasets/data/cars.json'
movies = 'https://vega.github.io/vega-datasets/data/movies.json'
sp500 = 'https://vega.github.io/vega-datasets/data/sp500.csv'
stocks = 'https://vega.github.io/vega-datasets/data/stocks.csv'
flights = 'https://vega.github.io/vega-datasets/data/flights-5k.json'

Interactive Charts With Altair¶

Charts made with Altair remain interactive. Example charts taken from this repo, specifically this notebook.

Example 1: DropDown¶

# single-value selection over [Major_Genre, MPAA_Rating] pairs
# use specific hard-wired values as the initial selected values
selection = alt.selection_single(
    name='Select',
    fields=['Major_Genre', 'MPAA_Rating'],
    init={'Major_Genre': 'Drama', 'MPAA_Rating': 'R'},
    bind={'Major_Genre': alt.binding_select(options=genres), 'MPAA_Rating': alt.binding_radio(options=mpaa)}
)
  
# scatter plot, modify opacity based on selection
alt.Chart(movies).mark_circle().add_selection(
    selection
).encode(
    x='Rotten_Tomatoes_Rating:Q',
    y='IMDB_Rating:Q',
    tooltip='Title:N',
    opacity=alt.condition(selection, alt.value(0.75), alt.value(0.05))
)

Example 2: Tooltips¶

alt.Chart(movies).mark_circle().add_selection(
    alt.selection_interval(bind='scales', encodings=['x'])
).encode(
    x='Rotten_Tomatoes_Rating:Q',
    y=alt.Y('IMDB_Rating:Q', axis=alt.Axis(minExtent=30)), # use min extent to stabilize axis title placement
    tooltip=['Title:N', 'Release_Date:N', 'IMDB_Rating:Q', 'Rotten_Tomatoes_Rating:Q']
).properties(
    width=600,
    height=400
)

Example 3: More Tooltips¶

# select a point for which to provide details-on-demand
label = alt.selection_single(
    encodings=['x'], # limit selection to x-axis value
    on='mouseover',  # select on mouseover events
    nearest=True,    # select data point nearest the cursor
    empty='none'     # empty selection includes no data points
)

# define our base line chart of stock prices
base = alt.Chart().mark_line().encode(
    alt.X('date:T'),
    alt.Y('price:Q', scale=alt.Scale(type='log')),
    alt.Color('symbol:N')
)

alt.layer(
    base, # base line chart
    
    # add a rule mark to serve as a guide line
    alt.Chart().mark_rule(color='#aaa').encode(
        x='date:T'
    ).transform_filter(label),
    
    # add circle marks for selected time points, hide unselected points
    base.mark_circle().encode(
        opacity=alt.condition(label, alt.value(1), alt.value(0))
    ).add_selection(label),

    # add white stroked text to provide a legible background for labels
    base.mark_text(align='left', dx=5, dy=-5, stroke='white', strokeWidth=2).encode(
        text='price:Q'
    ).transform_filter(label),

    # add text labels for stock prices
    base.mark_text(align='left', dx=5, dy=-5).encode(
        text='price:Q'
    ).transform_filter(label),
    
    data=stocks
).properties(
    width=700,
    height=400
)

Data Tables¶

You can display tables per the usual way in your blog:

movies = 'https://vega.github.io/vega-datasets/data/movies.json'
df = pd.read_json(movies)
# display table with pandas
df[['Title', 'Worldwide_Gross', 
    'Production_Budget', 'IMDB_Rating']].head()
Title Worldwide_Gross Production_Budget IMDB_Rating
0 The Land Girls 146083.0 8000000.0 6.1
1 First Love, Last Rites 10876.0 300000.0 6.9
2 I Married a Strange Person 203134.0 250000.0 6.8
3 Let's Talk About Sex 373615.0 300000.0 NaN
4 Slam 1087521.0 1000000.0 3.4

Images¶

Local Images¶

You can reference local images and they will be copied and rendered on your blog automatically. You can include these with the following markdown syntax:

![](my_icons/fastai_logo.png)

Remote Images¶

Remote images can be included with the following markdown syntax:

![](https://image.flaticon.com/icons/svg/36/36686.svg)

Animated Gifs¶

Animated Gifs work, too!

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/71/ChessPawnSpecialMoves.gif)

Captions¶

You can include captions with markdown images like this:

![](https://www.fast.ai/images/fastai_paper/show_batch.png "Credit: https://www.fast.ai/2020/02/13/fastai-A-Layered-API-for-Deep-Learning/")

Other Elements¶

Tweetcards¶

Typing > twitter: https://twitter.com/jakevdp/status/1204765621767901185?s=20 will render this:

Altair 4.0 is released! https://t.co/PCyrIOTcvv
Try it with:

pip install -U altair

The full list of changes is at https://t.co/roXmzcsT58 ...read on for some highlights. pic.twitter.com/vWJ0ZveKbZ

— Jake VanderPlas (@jakevdp) December 11, 2019

Youtube Videos¶

Typing > youtube: https://youtu.be/XfoYk_Z5AkI will render this:

Boxes / Callouts¶

Typing > Warning: There will be no second warning! will render this:

Warning: There will be no second warning!

Typing > Important: Pay attention! It's important. will render this:

Important: Pay attention! It’s important.

Typing > Tip: This is my tip. will render this:

Tip: This is my tip.

Typing > Note: Take note of this. will render this:

Note: Take note of this.

Typing > Note: A doc link to [an example website: fast.ai](https://www.fast.ai/) should also work fine. will render in the docs:

Note: A doc link to an example website: fast.ai should also work fine.

2019 . 2019 , .

  • tensorflow code keras code .

entry.title: Example Markdown Post
entry.content:
Basic setup

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-filename.md

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and filename is whatever file name you choose, to remind yourself what this post is about. .md is the file extension for markdown files.

The first line of the file should start with a single hash character, then a space, then your title. This is how you create a level 1 heading in markdown. Then you can create level 2, 3, etc headings as you wish but repeating the hash character, such as you see in the line ## File names above.

Basic formatting

You can use italics, bold, code font text, and create links. Heres a footnote 1. Heres a horizontal rule:

Lists

Heres a list:

  • item 1
  • item 2

And a numbered list:

  1. item 1
  2. item 2

Boxes and stuff

This is a quotation

You can include alert boxes

and

You can include info boxes

Images

Code

General preformatted text:

# Do a thing
do_thing()

Python code and output:

# Prints '2'
print(1+1)

2

Tables

Column 1 Column 2
A thing Another thing

Tweetcards

Altair 4.0 is released! https://t.co/PCyrIOTcvv
Try it with:

pip install -U altair

The full list of changes is at https://t.co/roXmzcsT58 ...read on for some highlights. pic.twitter.com/vWJ0ZveKbZ

— Jake VanderPlas (@jakevdp) December 11, 2019

Footnotes

  1. This is the footnote.↩

entry.title: BERT
entry.content:
BERT, Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers

Abstract

BERT unlabeled text deep bidirectional representation pretrain . layer context .

pretrained BERT output layer fine-tuning question answering language inference state-of-the-art . task-specific .

1. Introduction

pretrained language representation .

  • Feature-based: ELMO

    task-specific architecture .

  • fine-tuning: OpenAI GPT

    task-specific parameter .

pretraining objective . unidirectional representation .

, unidirectional representation pretrained representation , fine-tuning . standard language models unidirectional architecture . , openAI GPT left-to-right architecture . self-attention layer . sentence-level task sub-optimal.

contribution .

  • Bidirectional pre-training for language representation
  • pre-trained representation task-specific architecture .
  • 11 NLP task SOTA .

2. Related Work

pre-training general language representations .

2.1 Unsupervised Feature-based Approaches

  • word embedding vectors

  • ELMO

2.2 Unsupervised Fine-tuning Approaches

word embedding parameter unlabeled text pre-trained .

  • OpenAI GPT

fine-tuning approach parameter .

2.3 Transfer Learning from Supervised Data

NLP, vision task tranfer learning .

  • Imagenet pretrained

3. BERT: unified architecture across different tasks.

BERT .

  • pre-training: unlabeled data .

  • fine-tuning: weight pre-trained . labeled data .

  • Model Architecture

    Transformer . Transformer encoder decoder , BERT encoder .

  • **Input/Output Representations **

    down-stream task , input representation single sentence a pair of sentence .

    WordPiece embeddings . token [CLS].(special classification token ) [CLS] hidden state classification task representation .

    sentence .

    1. special token [SEP] sentence .
    2. sentence sentence embedding sentence .

3.1 Pre-training BERT

  • Task #1: Masked LM

    , bidirectional representation unidirectional representation . , bidirectional representation , word , multi layerd contex target word .

    deep bidirectional representation train input token mask . masked LM(MLM) . 15% token .

    , fine-tuning , . [Mask] token fine-tuning . , .

    1. i-token mask, 80% [Mask] .

      . -> [Mask].

    2. i-token mask, 10% random .

      -> .

    3. i-token mask, 10% .

      . -> .

    , Transformer layer cross entropy loss . random $0.15 * 0.1 = 0.015$ .

  • Task #2: Next Sentence Prediction(NSP)

    Question Answering, Natural Language Inference task . language modeling . next sentence prediction task pre-train .

    • A B , 50% B .
    • 50% random .

    , sentence embedding down-task . (BERT parameter .)

3.2 Fine-tunning BERT

  • self-attention layer fine-tuning .
  • input sequence representation , [CLS] token Transformer output .
  • [CLS] token H . $CR^H$
  • classify (K) classification layer . classification layer : $WR^{KH} WR^{KH}$
  • label probabilities standard softmax .$P=softmax(CWT)P=softmax(CWT)$

  • W matrix BERT fine-tuning .

  • hyperparmeter

    Batch size: 16, 32 Learning rage (Adam): 5e-5, 3e-5, 2e-5 Number of epochs : 3, 4

  • pretraining , fine-tuning .

  • fine-tuning dataset hyperparameter training .

3.3 Comparision of BERT, ELMO and OpenAI GPT

  • BERT OpenAI GPT fine-tuning approach , ELMo feature-based approach.
  • BERT OpenAI GPT pre-training .
  • BERT ELMo bidirectional representation . OpenAI GPT unidirectional representation .

4.Experiments

  • Fine-tunning on Different Tasks

task fine-tuning . (a), (b) sentence level, (c) (d) token-level task. [CLS] classification , [SEP] token .

  • GLUE

  • SQuAD v1.1

  • SQuAD v2.0

  • SWAG

5. Ablation Studies

5.1 Effect of Pre-training Tasks

5.1 Effect of Model Size

5.3 Feature-based Approach with BERT

6. Conclusion

entry.title: Content
entry.content:
• Insert sort
  • Merge sort
  • Quick sort
  • Heap sort

Insert Sort

insert sort .

insert sort , . , i , 0 ~ i 0 ~ i . i + 1 0 ~ i .

.

for i in range(1, len(A)):
    key = A[i] #    
    # Insert into the sorted sequence A[:i]
    j = i - 1
    while j > 0 and A[j] > key:
        A[j + 1] = A[j]
        j -= 1
    A[j + 1] = key

.

Loop invariants and the correctness of insertion sort

i index , A[:i] 0 ~ i - 1 . A[:i ] A[:i] . CS loop invariants . correcteness .

loop invariants 3 .

  • Initialization: .
  • Maintenance: , .
  • Termination: , loop invariant .

.

A = [0, 3, 8, 2, 1, 4]

  • Initialization

    index 1 .(A[i] = 3) A[:i] = [0]. .\

  • Maintenance

    i 1, 2, 3, 4 . subarray A[:i] A[:i] . (Loop invariant)

  • Termination

    . (i = len(A) - 1)

    , i 1 , i=len(A) - 1 . subarray A[:i] 0 ~ len(A) - 2 . ( .) A[i] .

Analyzing algorithms

  • input size: array size
  • running time: input call

  • best case: O(N)/O(1)
    • $c_5 \sum_{j=2}^n t_j + c_6 \sum_{j=2}^n (t_j - 1) + c_7 \sum_{j=2}^n (t_j - 1)$ .
  • worst case: O(N^2)/O(1)
  • order of growth: O(N^2)/O(1)
    • upper bound

Merge sort: devide-and-conquer

devide-and-conquer .

  • devide: problem -> subproblem, subproblem problem .
  • conquer: subproblem , .
  • combine: subproblem problem .

merge sort devide-and-conquer .

  • devide: array 2 array .
  • conquer: array .
  • combine: array , array .

merge sort . python .

Top-Down approach: recursive


def merge(A, p, q, r):
    """
    A[p:q+1] A[q+1:r+1] . 
    A:   array, A[p:q+1], A[q+1:r+1]   
    """
    arr, i = [0] * (r - p + 1), 0
    while p < q and q < r:
       	if A[p] < A[q]:
            arr[i] = A[p]
            p += 1
        else:
            arr[i] = A[q]
            q += 1
    
    if p < q - p - 1:
        arr[i+1:] = A[p:q+1]
    if q < r - q - 2:
        arr[i+1: ] = A[q+1:r+1]
    A[p:r+1] = arr


def merge_sort(A, p, r):
    '''
    A:   array
    p: left index
    r: right index
    '''
    if p < r:
        q =  (p + r) // 2
        merge_sort(A, p, q)
        merge_sort(A, q + 1, r)
        merge(A, p, q, r)

Bottom-up approach: iterative

def merge(A, p, q, r):
    """
    A[p:q+1] A[q+1:r+1] . 
    A:   array
    """
    arr, i = [0] * (r - p + 1), 0
    while p < q and q < r:
       	if A[p] < A[q]:
            arr[i] = A[p]
            p += 1
        else:
            arr[i] = A[q]
            q += 1
    
    if p < q - p - 1:
        arr[i+1:] = A[p:q+1]
    if q < r - q - 2:
        arr[i+1: ] = A[q+1:r+1]
    A[p:r+1] = arr


group_size = 1
while group_size < len(A):
   	i = 0
    while i < len(A):
        merge(A, i, i + group_size, i + 2*group_size + 1)
        i += group_size * 2 + 2
    group_size *= 2

Loop invariant

insert sort loop invariant corrteness .

  • Initialization: subarray .
  • Maintainance: subarray index .
  • Termination: subarray . subarray . merge , .

Analyzing divide-and-conquer algorithms

recursive , running time recurrence equation . .

  • subarray : $\mbox{if } n > c$
  • $T(n/b)$: $n/b$ subarray , $a$ subarray
  • $D(n)$: array subarray
  • $C(n)$: combine

merge sort .

  • divide: $D(n) = O(1)$, subarray .
  • conquer: $2T(N/2)$
  • combine: $C(n) = O(n)$

  • time complexity: O(nlogn)
  • space complexity: O(nlogn)

Quick Sort

  • worst case: O(n ^ 2)

  • expected: O(nlogn) constant factor .

quick sort divide-and-conquer .

  • Divide: Array subarray . $A[pr]$ $A[p..q-1]$,$A[q + 1.. r]$

    . $A[p..q-1]$ $A[q]$ . $A[q + 1.. r]$ $A[q]$ . $A[q]$ pivot.

  • Conquer: $A[p..q-1]$,$A[q + 1.. r]$ .

  • Combine: subarray , .

quick sort .

def quick_sort(A, p, r):
    if p < r:
        q = partition(A, p, r)
        quick_sort(A, p, q - 1)
        quick_sort(A, q + 1, r)
        
def partition(A, p, r):
    x = A[r] # pivot value
    i = p - 1
    for j in range(p, r-1):
        if A[j] <= x: # pivot  .
            i += 1
            A[i], A[j] = A[j], A[i]
   	A[i+1], A[r] = A[r], A[i + 1]
    return i + 1

partition . i index pivot , j index .

Loop invariant

  • Initialization

    i = p - 1 j = p . p i value . i + 1 j- 1 . loop invariant . (swap .)

  • Maintainance

    , pivot value . , .

  • Termination

    3 set . pivot set, pivot, pivot set , .

Performance of quicksort

  • worst-case

    partitioning 1: n-1 O(N^2).

  • balanced partioning

    partitioning O(NlogN).
entry.summary: Insert sort Merge sort Quick sort Heap sort

entry.title: Big-O notation
entry.content:
In computer science, big O notation is used to classify algorithms according to how their running time or space requirements grow as the input size grows.[3] In analytic number theory, big O notation is often used to express a bound on the difference between an arithmetical function and a better understood approximation; a famous example of such a difference is the remainder term in the prime number theorem.

reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation

Formal definition

$F$ real or complex valued function , $g$ real valued function. subset . $g(x)$ x .

x , $F(x)$ $g(x)$ , $F(x) = O(g(x))$ . (Upper Bound) .

.

$Mg(x)$ $F(x)$ . $x_0$ x , $F(x)$ $Mg(x)$ , $F(x)$ upper bound $Mg(x)$ .
entry.summary: In computer science, big O notation is used to classify algorithms according to how their running time or space requirements grow as the input size grows.[3] In analytic number theory, big O notation is often used to express a bound on the difference between an arithmetical function and a better understood approximation; a famous example of such a difference is the remainder term in the prime number theorem. reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation

entry.title: Transformer
entry.content:
Transformer . encoder decoder . encoder layer output decoder stack input . (residual connection) encoder layer decoder layer parameter . 6 layer .

encoder decoder .

layer Normalization bias .

Matrix Calculation of Self-Attention

embeddinb vector matrix . embedding vector matrix . .

Attention

1. Scaled Dot-Product Attention

Query, Key - Value

  • Query: , matrix
  • Key: embedding vector key, matrix
  • Value: key value, matrix

query key, value query key . query key dot-product softmax , query key . query key . value value scaling .

key value . key vector value vector . key value attention .

reference: https://reniew.github.io/43/

scaled dot product attention . query, key value $W^Q, W^K, W^V$matrix dot product .

query key dot product $\sqrt{d_k}$ scaling .

\

2. Multi-Head Attention

  • $W_i^Q \in R_{d_{model} \times d_k}$
  • $W_i^K \in R_{d_{model} \times d_k}$
  • $W_i^V \in R_{d_{model} \times d_k}$

multi head attention . .

  • model . The animal didnt cross the street because it was too tired it .
  • layer multiple representation subspace . Q, K, V matrix random .

embedding vector(Thinking, Machines) head .

Representing The Order of The Sequence Using Positional Encoding

attention word . ?

entry.title: Abstract
entry.content:
depth estimation . , , ground-truth data . , depth . binocular stereo footage .

epipolar geometry constraints reconstruction loss . depth image . , consistency loss .

Epipolar geometry

stereo vision geometry,

2 3D . 3D points 2D points .

Introduction

multiple observation . multiple viewpoint data . , supervised learning mono depth estimation . data depth . , .(depth )

image machine perception .

monocular depth estimation .

  • etc

top-down, bottom-up depth . depth data . synthesize depth . (left view, right view) pixel level . (regression) .

  • memory issue
  • not fully diferentiable

Related Work

Learning-Based Stereo: between two images

SSIM: structural similarity

. SSIM . x y brightness, contrast, structure .

  • brightness

    $u_x$: x

    $u_y$: y

    $I(x, y) = \frac{2u_xu_y + C_1}{u_x^2 + u_y^2 + C_2}$

  • contrast

    $C(x, y) = \frac{2\sigma_x\sigma_y+C_2}{\sigma_x^2 + \sigma_y^2 + C_2}$

  • structure

    structure = $\frac{x-u_x}{\sigma_x}$

    $S(x, y) = \frac{\sigma_{xy} + C_3}{\sigma_x\sigma_y + C_3}$

  • SSIM

    $SSIM(x,y) = I(x,y)C(c,y)S(x,y)$

    $SSIM(x, y)= \frac{(2u_xu_y + C_1) (2\sigma_{xy} +C_2)}{(u_x^2 + u_y^2 + C_1)(\sigma_x^2 + \sigma_y^2 +C_2)}$
